Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award is to significantly enhance the formability of thin sheet metals and the dimensional accuracy of formed features at the micrometer scale by integrating high-density electrical current with mechanical deformation through an instrumented desktop rolling mill. Two fundamental questions will be addressed in achieving the objectives: (1) how electrical current affects the plasticity and residual stress of metals subjected to deformation; and (2) how to realize in-process measurement for effective microrolling process control. The planned research tasks are: (1) Experimental characterization and constitutive modeling of material behavior subjected to mechanical and electrical loading; (2) Multi-physics modeling of mechanical stress, thermal and electro-magnetic fields in the microrolling process and mill structure; (3) In process sensing and data mapping for process characterization; and (4) System integration.
If successful, the new hybrid process will reduce process design complexity, reduce energy consumption, and reduce chemical wastes in achieving thin metal foils with desired surface finish. The new sensing methods and instrument design will push the current limits of the rolling process in terms of size, precision, cost, and energy efficiency. One of the many uses of the metal foil is micro-electrodes and contacts for the next generation of bio-implants, such as pacemakers for treating heart disorders, deep brain simulation electrodes for potentially treating Parkinson?s disease, depression, dystonia or chronic pain, and artificial pancreas for monitoring and developing new therapeutics that regulate Type 1 Diabetes. Device miniaturization enabled by microrolling will benefit patients by improving their quality of life. The collaboration between academic institutions and industry will inspire the innovations and talents needed for U.S. manufacturing companies to remain competitive. The project will provide training to graduate and undergraduate students and practitioners through research opportunities, class projects, short courses, and internships.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this project is to test the hypothesis that, the integration of electric current with mechanical deformation, through an instrumented desktop rolling mill, can significantly enhance the forming capability of thin sheet metals. A new process, electrically-assisted (EA) micro-rolling, in which a high-density electric current is utilized in the forming zone, was developed to enhance forming ability of the process. By achieving these goals, tasks of material characterization under current load and understanding of the factors affecting electrically-assisted process effectiveness have been accomplished.

 

To maximize the effectiveness of electric current in electrically-assisted micro-rolling, investigation of material behavior under electric load is necessary. Through a novel EA tensile test, it has been shown that the Joule heating effect is the dominant factor for flow stress reduction under a continuous current or current with a pulse duration longer than a few milliseconds. Figure 1 shows our experimental result, i.e., flow stress reduction was eliminated when forced air cooling was applied to remove the Joule heating effect (Fig. 1). With this understanding, a thermal-mechanical model was developed, as shown in Fig. 2, to predict the amount of flow stress reduction as a function of applied current density and material properties, such as resistivity. Generally, metal with higher electrical resistivity responded with a more significant Joule heating effect.

 

Knowing the roles and effect of electric current in metal forming, electrically-assisted forming was demonstrated in a micro-rolling-based texturing process. Aluminum and titanium were selected to validate the results found in material characterization, as mentioned in the previous paragraph. These two materials have significant difference in their sensitivity to current. Micro channels were formed on Al and Ti alloys by micro-rolling-based texturing and electrically-assisted micro-rolling-based texturing.  Experimental results showed that more significant improvement of channel depth was found in Ti alloy than the Al alloy. Additionally, the Joule heating effect depends on the current flow direction in the micro-rolling system because the current passage area is geometric dependent. In micro-rolling, current flowing from one roll to the other provides more significant Joule heating effect in texturing. Additionally, an analytical model was developed to predict the micro channel depth formed by electrically-assisted micro-rolling-based texturing.

 

To monitor the localized effects, such as pressure, within the forming zone in micro-rolling, an embedded capacitive sensor has been developed to measure the temporal and spatial distributions of pressure across the roll-workpiece interface. The embedded sensor was embedded into one of the two work rolls 1-2 mm underneath its surface. Electrodes were aligned along the sensing rod. Their capacities changed with roll surface elastic deformation when they rolled over the forming zone and, consequently, the pressure distribution along the forming zone can be found with an experimental validated capacitive-pressure relationship. The embedded sensor was designed, fabricated and installed to a roll for electrically-assisted micro-rolling-based texturing. It functioned properly under electric current and experimental results showed that the measured pressure distribution was well correlated with micro channel volume. Furthermore, a wireless version of the embedded sensor had also been fabricated, tested and employed in the process successfully.

 

In conclusion, the newly developed process, electrically-assisted micro-rolling, i...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The research objective of this project is to test the hypothesis that, the integration of electric current with mechanical deformation, through an instrumented desktop rolling mill, can significantly enhance the forming capability of thin sheet metals. A new process, electrically-assisted (EA) micro-rolling, in which a high-density electric current is utilized in the forming zone, was developed to enhance forming ability of the process. By achieving these goals, tasks of material characterization under current load and understanding of the factors affecting electrically-assisted process effectiveness have been accomplished. To maximize the effectiveness of electric current in electrically-assisted micro-rolling, investigation of material behavior under electric load is necessary. Through a novel EA tensile test, it has been shown that the Joule heating effect is the dominant factor for flow stress reduction under a continuous current or current with a pulse duration longer than a few milliseconds. Figure 1 shows our experimental result, i.e., flow stress reduction was eliminated when forced air cooling was applied to remove the Joule heating effect (Fig. 1). With this understanding, a thermal-mechanical model was developed, as shown in Fig. 2, to predict the amount of flow stress reduction as a function of applied current density and material properties, such as resistivity. Generally, metal with higher electrical resistivity responded with a more significant Joule heating effect. Knowing the roles and effect of electric current in metal forming, electrically-assisted forming was demonstrated in a micro-rolling-based texturing process. Aluminum and titanium were selected to validate the results found in material characterization, as mentioned in the previous paragraph. These two materials have significant difference in their sensitivity to current. Micro channels were formed on Al and Ti alloys by micro-rolling-based texturing and electrically-assisted micro-rolling-based texturing. Experimental results showed that more significant improvement of channel depth was found in Ti alloy than the Al alloy. Additionally, the Joule heating effect depends on the current flow direction in the micro-rolling system because the current passage area is geometric dependent. In micro-rolling, current flowing from one roll to the other provides more significant Joule heating effect in texturing. Additionally, an analytical model was developed to predict the micro channel depth formed by electrically-assisted micro-rolling-based texturing. To monitor the localized effects, such as pressure, within the forming zone in micro-rolling, an embedded capacitive sensor has been developed to measure the temporal and spatial distributions of pressure across the roll-workpiece interface. The embedded sensor was embedded into one of the two work rolls 1-2 mm underneath its surface. Electrodes were aligned along the sensing rod. Their capacities changed with roll surface elastic deformation when they rolled over the forming zone and, consequently, the pressure distribution along the forming zone can be found with an experimental validated capacitive-pressure relationship. The embedded sensor was designed, fabricated and installed to a roll for electrically-assisted micro-rolling-based texturing. It functioned properly under electric current and experimental results showed that the measured pressure distribution was well correlated with micro channel volume. Furthermore, a wireless version of the embedded sensor had also been fabricated, tested and employed in the process successfully. In conclusion, the newly developed process, electrically-assisted micro-rolling, improved the formability of material, as well as process performance. By integrating the embedded sensor to the system, better monitoring on forming pressure distribution in the forming zone can be achieved.
